lesson_title: At the Market: Buying and Selling
objectives: Learn words for common things we buy and sell in the market.
Practice talking to shopkeepers and asking about prices.
Understand how to buy things and use polite words when shopping.

sections.text: In the market, we buy many fresh vegetables and fruits. Knowing their English names helps us ask for them easily.

examples.label: Potato
examples.value: A common vegetable, brown outside, white inside. We use it in many curries.

examples.label: Onion
examples.value: A vegetable with many layers, used in almost all cooking for flavor.

examples.label: Tomato
examples.value: A red, juicy fruit used as a vegetable in curries and salads.

examples.label: Spinach
examples.value: Green leafy vegetable, very healthy. We grow a lot of it in our fields.

examples.label: Mango
examples.value: A very sweet and juicy fruit, popular in summer. Our village has many mango trees.

examples.label: Banana
examples.value: A long yellow fruit, easy to peel and eat. Monkeys also love bananas!

usage_examples: I want to buy some fresh **potatoes** for dinner.
How much are these **onions**?
My mother needs three **tomatoes** for the curry.
This **spinach** is very fresh from the farm.
I love eating sweet **mangoes** in summer.
Please give me a bunch of **bananas**.
Are there any fresh **carrots** today?
We use **chilies** to make food spicy.

sections.text: Besides vegetables and fruits, we also buy grains, pulses (dal), and other food items from the market or shop.

examples.label: Rice
examples.value: The main food grain, cooked and eaten daily. Our farmers grow a lot of rice.

examples.label: Wheat
examples.value: A grain used to make flour for roti or bread.

examples.label: Dal (Lentils)
examples.value: Dried pulses like Toor Dal, Moong Dal, cooked as a curry. They are very healthy.

examples.label: Sugar
examples.value: Sweet crystals used to make tea, sweets, and other dishes.

examples.label: Salt
examples.value: A white powder that adds taste to food. Food tastes bland without salt.

examples.label: Oil
examples.value: Used for cooking food. We often use groundnut oil or mustard oil.

usage_examples: I need five kilograms of **rice** for my home.
My mother buys **wheat** flour to make chapatis.
Please give me one kilogram of **dal**.
Do you have some **sugar** for my tea?
Don't forget to add **salt** to the curry.
We need a bottle of cooking **oil**.
The shopkeeper sells fresh **jaggery**.
I want to buy some **biscuits** and **tea powder**.

sections.text: When you want to know the cost of something, these are the basic questions you can ask. Always remember to be polite.

examples.label: How much is this?
examples.value: Use this when you are holding one item or pointing to one item.

examples.label: How much are these?
examples.value: Use this when you are holding or pointing to many items (plural).

examples.label: What is the price of this?
examples.value: Another way to ask for the cost of one item.

examples.label: How much per kilo?
examples.value: Used when asking the price of items sold by weight (kilogram).

usage_examples: Excuse me, **how much is this** mango?
Sir, **how much are these** potatoes?
Shopkeeper: '**What is the price of this** shirt?'
How much is the rice **per kilo**?
**How much is this** toy car?
Are these chilies expensive? **How much per kilo**?
Excuse me, **what is the price of this** new broom?

sections.text: When the shopkeeper tells you the price, you need to understand the numbers. Prices are usually given in rupees. Sometimes, they may say 'per kilo', 'per dozen', or 'per piece'.

examples.label: 10 Rupees
examples.value: Means the item costs 10 Indian Rupees. Example: 'This apple is 10 rupees.'

examples.label: 50 Rupees per kilo
examples.value: Means one kilogram of the item costs 50 rupees. Example: 'Potatoes are 50 rupees per kilo.'

examples.label: 20 Rupees per dozen
examples.value: Means 12 pieces of the item cost 20 rupees. Example: 'Bananas are 20 rupees per dozen.'

examples.label: 5 Rupees a piece
examples.value: Means one piece of the item costs 5 rupees. Example: 'This cookie is 5 rupees a piece.'

usage_examples: Shopkeeper: 'The tomatoes are **40 rupees per kilo**.'
Customer: 'I bought this pen for **10 rupees**.'
Bananas are **30 rupees per dozen** at this stall.
How many eggs are in a dozen? Twelve.
The small clay pot is **25 rupees**.
Rice is usually sold **per kilo**.
A small pack of biscuits is **5 rupees**.

sections.text: In many village markets, you can try to get a lower price. This is called bargaining. Use these polite phrases.

examples.label: Is there any discount?
examples.value: Asking if the price can be made a little lower.

examples.label: Can you reduce the price?
examples.value: Politely asking the shopkeeper to make the item cheaper.

examples.label: It's a bit expensive.
examples.value: Saying that the price is high to suggest a lower price.

examples.label: Can you give it for...?
examples.value: Suggesting a lower price you are willing to pay. Example: 'Can you give it for 40 rupees?'

usage_examples: Shopkeeper: 'This cloth is 200 rupees.' Customer: 'Sir, **is there any discount** on this?'
This mango basket is 150 rupees. **Can you reduce the price** a little?
The new shirt looks good, but **it's a bit expensive** for me.
Can you give these vegetables for **50 rupees**?
My mother always tries to **bargain** for vegetables.
Shopkeeper: 'No bargaining.' Customer: 'Okay, I will pay the full price.'

sections.text: After agreeing on the price, you pay the money. Remember to check your change!

examples.label: Here is the money.
examples.value: Used when you hand over the payment.

examples.label: Do you have change?
examples.value: Asking if the shopkeeper can give you back smaller money.

examples.label: Where is my change?
examples.value: Asking for the money that should be returned to you.

examples.label: Keep the change.
examples.value: Used if the amount of change is very small and you don't want it back (optional).

usage_examples: Shopkeeper: 'That will be 70 rupees.' Customer: '**Here is the money**, sir.'
I gave a 100-rupee note. 'Do you have **change** for 100?'
After paying, I asked, '**Where is my change**?'
The total was 98 rupees. I said, 'Here is 100, **keep the change**.'
Always count your **change** carefully.
The shopkeeper returned the exact **change**.

topics.title: 4. Different Stalls and People at the Market

sections.text: A market has different sections or small shops (stalls) where different types of things are sold.

examples.label: Vegetable Stall
examples.value: A place where fresh vegetables are sold by a vendor.

examples.label: Fruit Stall
examples.value: A place where fresh fruits are sold.

examples.label: Grocery Shop
examples.value: A shop selling food items like rice, dal, sugar, oil, biscuits, etc.

examples.label: Clothes Shop
examples.value: A shop selling shirts, saris, dhoti, and other clothing.

examples.label: General Store
examples.value: A shop selling a variety of daily use items, not just food.

usage_examples: My mother buys fresh vegetables from the **vegetable stall**.
We bought sweet mangoes from the **fruit stall**.
The **grocery shop** in our village sells everything we need.
I need a new shirt from the **clothes shop**.
We visit the market's **sweet shop** for laddus.
The **fish market** smells strong but has fresh fish.

sections.text: Many different people work or visit the market every day. Knowing their roles helps you understand the market better.

examples.label: Shopkeeper
examples.value: A person who owns or works in a shop and sells things.

examples.label: Vendor
examples.value: A person who sells things, often from a small stall or cart in the market.

examples.label: Customer / Buyer
examples.value: A person who goes to the market to buy things.

examples.label: Seller
examples.value: A person who offers goods for sale.

usage_examples: The **shopkeeper** gave me a good price.
The **vegetable vendor** was calling out loudly.
I am a **customer** at this market today.
Many **buyers** come to our village market on Sundays.
The **seller** showed me many different saris.
The **shopkeeper** weighed the rice for me.

sections.text: These are some general phrases you can use when you are shopping in a market or shop.

examples.label: I want to buy...
examples.value: State what you wish to purchase. Example: 'I want to buy some fruits.'

examples.label: Do you have...?
examples.value: Ask if the shop sells a particular item. Example: 'Do you have fresh milk?'

examples.label: Show me...
examples.value: Ask the seller to show you a specific item. Example: 'Show me those red apples.'

examples.label: That's all, thank you.
examples.value: Used when you have finished buying and are ready to pay.

examples.label: Have a good day!
examples.value: A polite way to say goodbye to the shopkeeper.

usage_examples: Excuse me, sir, **I want to buy** some sugar.
**Do you have** any fresh vegetables today?
Please **show me** the new shirts.
Okay, **that's all, thank you**.
After shopping, I said, '**Have a good day**!' to the shopkeeper.
What can I help you with today?
I am just looking, thank you.
Is this vegetable fresh?
I like this color.
